profileText: A Representative from Virginia; born in James City County, Va., September 13, 1837; attended the schools of Williamsburg, College of William and Mary, and the University of Virginia at Charlottesville; studied medicine; was graduated from the University of the City of New York March 4, 1861; returned to Virginia, and during the Civil War enlisted in the Thirty-second Regiment of Virginia Infantry, Confederate Army; assistant surgeon in charge of Artillery battalion; promoted to surgeon March 10, 1864, and served until the surrender at Appomattox April 9, 1865; settled in Isle of Wight County, Va., December 1865; practiced medicine for ten years, when he engaged in agricultural pursuits; member of the State house of delegates 1869-1873; served in the State senate 1874-1877; again a member of the State house of delegates in 1883 and 1884; elected as a Democrat to the Fifty-second Congress (March 4, 1891-March 3, 1893); was not a candidate for renomination in 1892; resumed farming; delegate to the State constitutional convention in 1901 and 1902; died in Smithfield, Va., on February 21, 1905; interment in Ivy Hill Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1860, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John William Lawson to James Dewitt Hankins written in 1860. In the letter, John William Lawson writes about the presidential election in New York and his own feelings about reconciliation and secession. He describes a secession meeting held by southern medical students at the University of New York, and reminisces about the Jefferson Society at the University of Virginia.

researchRecord.name: 1890, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from W. W. Griggs to John William Lawson written on November 6, 1890. In the letter, W. W. Griggs congratulates John William Lawson on his election to Congress and recalls a meeting of secession-minded students at New York University.
